Propor recomendações baseadas em evidências (ex: ajustar o projeto para aumentar inclusão)
Comunicar resultados a stakeholders de forma clara e acessível (ex: apresentações, relatórios)
Planejar implementação considerando feedback e ajustes contínuos
steps.verification: Apresentar um plano de ação detalhado com justificativa baseada nas análises e critérios de sustentabilidade
steps.materials: Relatórios anteriores, ferramentas de comunicação (ex: PowerPoint), softwares de colaboração (ex: Google Docs)
steps.tips: Inclua cenários alternativos (ex: pior caso, melhor caso) na análise para testar a robustez das decisões
steps.learningObjective: Tomar decisões informadas que equilibrem viabilidade econômica e justiça social em projetos de ciência e tecnologia
steps.commonMistakes: Decidir sem considerar todos os stakeholders ou ignorar dados contraditórios que possam afetar a sustentabilidade

atomicExpansion.practicalExample: Avaliar a implementação de um sistema de energia solar em uma comunidade rural, considerando custos de instalação (ex: painéis, inversores), impactos na redução da conta de energia local, geração de empregos na manutenção, e inclusão de famílias de baixa renda através de subsídios ou programas de acesso.
finalVerifications: Análise financeira completa com cálculos de retorno sobre investimento (ROI) e valor presente líquido (VPL)
Matriz de impacto social detalhada com indicadores quantificados (ex: número de empregos criados, percentual de famílias beneficiadas)
Relatório integrado que sintetiza aspectos econômicos e sociais, destacando trade-offs e recomendações
Plano de ação com recomendações baseadas em critérios de sustentabilidade, incluindo etapas de implementação e monitoramento
assessmentCriteria: Precisão nos cálculos financeiros e sociais, com uso adequado de ferramentas e dados
Clareza na integração de critérios múltiplos, demonstrando compreensão de trade-offs
Adequação das recomendações ao contexto real, considerando viabilidade e impacto social
Qualidade da comunicação dos resultados, incluindo visualizações e linguagem acessível para stakeholders
crossCurricularConnections: Economia: aplicação de análise de custo-benefício, finanças e microeconomia em projetos sustentáveis
Sociologia: estudos de impacto social, equidade e dinâmicas comunitárias em inovações tecnológicas
Engenharia: design sustentável, gestão de projetos e implementação de soluções técnicas com considerações sociais
Ética: reflexão sobre justiça, bem-estar comunitário e responsabilidade em decisões de ciência e tecnologia
atomicExpansion.realWorldApplication: Aplicado em projetos de engenharia civil para infraestruturas sustentáveis, como construção de pontes ou edifícios verdes, onde decisões de design devem equilibrar custos de materiais, benefícios sociais (ex: acessibilidade, criação de empregos) e impactos ambientais, assegurando que inovações promovam desenvolvimento econômico inclusivo e justiça social.

specificSkills.name: Propor soluções sustentáveis para problemas tecnológicos
specificSkills.description: Desenvolver e argumentar em favor de alternativas ou melhorias em tecnologias existentes que aumentem a sustentabilidade, como uso de energias renováveis, materiais biodegradáveis ou designs eficientes.

steps.title: Identify and Define the Technological Problem
subSteps: Define the specific technological issue requiring a solution
Identify key sustainability criteria such as energy efficiency, waste reduction, or social impact
Assess the current state's environmental and societal impacts using available data
Set clear boundaries and scope for the problem analysis
Document the analysis in a preliminary report
steps.verification: Completion of a problem analysis report that includes defined sustainability criteria and impact assessment
steps.materials: Computers with internet access, documentation software (e.g., Microsoft Word or Google Docs), reference materials on sustainability principles
steps.tips: Use a structured approach like SWOT analysis to break down the problem into manageable parts
steps.learningObjective: To learn how to systematically analyze technological problems from a sustainability perspective
steps.commonMistakes: Focusing only on direct impacts and neglecting long-term or indirect effects; vague problem statements

steps.title: Research Sustainable Alternatives
subSteps: Conduct literature review on sustainable technologies relevant to the problem
Gather data on potential solutions, including renewable energy options, biodegradable materials, or efficient designs
Compare alternatives based on metrics like carbon footprint, cost, and scalability
Consult case studies or expert opinions to validate findings
Create a comparative table summarizing key aspects of each alternative
steps.verification: Comparative table of at least three sustainable alternatives with detailed metrics completed
steps.materials: Access to academic databases (e.g., Scopus, Web of Science), data analysis software (e.g., Excel or R), calculators for preliminary calculations
steps.tips: Prioritize peer-reviewed sources to ensure the reliability of information
steps.learningObjective: To develop skills in researching and evaluating sustainable technological options
steps.commonMistakes: Relying on outdated sources; not considering the entire life cycle of technologies

steps.title: Develop and Justify the Proposed Solution
subSteps: Synthesize research findings to design a coherent sustainable solution
Apply sustainability frameworks (e.g., triple bottom line) to justify the proposal
Calculate expected benefits, such as reduction in greenhouse gas emissions or resource savings
Address potential challenges and propose mitigation strategies
Draft a comprehensive proposal document that includes all calculations and justifications
steps.verification: Draft proposal document with integrated solution design, calculations, and justification
steps.materials: Design and simulation software if applicable (e.g., AutoCAD for engineering designs, Simulink for systems), calculators, tools for environmental impact assessment
steps.tips: Incorporate feedback loops to refine the solution based on iterative testing or simulations
steps.learningObjective: To create and argue for a sustainable technological solution with evidence-based reasoning
steps.commonMistakes: Overcomplicating the solution without clear benefits; inadequate justification of sustainability claims

steps.title: Present and Argue for the Solution
subSteps: Prepare visual aids and presentation materials to communicate the proposal
Structure arguments to highlight sustainability advantages and feasibility
Practice delivery to ensure clarity and persuasiveness
Simulate a Q&A session to anticipate and prepare for criticisms
Present the solution to peers or instructors and gather feedback
steps.verification: Successful presentation delivery and documentation of feedback received
steps.materials: Presentation software (e.g., PowerPoint or Prezi), visual design tools, recording equipment for practice sessions
steps.tips: Use storytelling techniques to make the proposal more engaging and relatable
steps.learningObjective: To effectively communicate and defend sustainable technological proposals in professional settings
steps.commonMistakes: Poor time management during presentation; inability to handle critical questions confidently

atomicExpansion.practicalExample: Designing a water purification system for a rural community that uses solar energy and locally available materials to ensure sustainability and reduce operational costs
finalVerifications: Proposal document is complete with all required sections
Comparative analysis of alternatives is included and justified
Presentation has been delivered and feedback documented
All calculations and sustainability assessments are verified for accuracy
assessmentCriteria: Clarity and organization of the proposal
Depth and accuracy of sustainability analysis
Quality and relevance of research sources
Effectiveness of argumentation and presentation
Innovation and practical feasibility of the solution
crossCurricularConnections: Physics: Understanding energy transformations in renewable systems
Chemistry: Knowledge of material properties and biodegradability
Environmental Science: Ecosystem impact assessments
Economics: Cost analysis and economic viability studies
atomicExpansion.realWorldApplication: Implementing sustainable solutions in industries such as manufacturing, where energy-efficient processes and waste reduction can lead to significant environmental and economic benefits
